A qubit is a superposition of the basis states \(|0⟩\) and \(|1⟩\), mathematically written as \(|ψ> = α|0⟩ +    β|1⟩\). We call α and β (both complex numbers) amplitudes of the basis states. They have the special property that \(|α|^2 + |β|^2 = 1\). Where \(|α|^2\) is the probability that the qubit is measured as \(0\) and \(|β|^2\) is the probability that the qubit is measured as \(1\). This makes sense, as a qubit can be measured only as either a \(0\) or \(1\). Acting as if they were real numbers, we could plot the state of a qubit on the unit circle. This establishes a dependence between α and β.


A Bloch Sphere is a graphical visualization of the state of a single qubit. On this sphere, the angles φ and θ are used to define a point on the sphere representing the superposition. For θ \(= 0\), the qubit is in the \(|0⟩\) state. For θ \(= π\), the qubit is in the \(|1⟩\) state. For θ \(= \frac{π}{2}\), the qubit has a 50% probability of being measured as \(0\) or \(1\). Simply, θ determines the horizontal displacement from the origin of the point and the vertical displacement of the point. The closer the superposition point is to a pole the greater the probability the qubit is measured as the state of that pole.

Glossary
ψ (psi) - superposition
φ (phi) - azimuthal angle of the bloch sphere; range of [0, 2π]
θ (the·ta) - polar angle of the bloch sphere; range of [0, π]
α (al·pha) - amplitude of the basis state
β (be·ta) - amplitude of the basis state
